description: Ethelburga Tower is a 17-storey block of flats near Battersea Park.  The building was designed by the LCC  Architects Dept with Ove Arup & Partners as consulting engineers.  It was built by Tersons of Finchley and completed in 1966.

events.name: Ethelburga Tower: general access
events.notes: Visitors can arrive at any time during the opening hours.There may be queues at busy times.

factsheet.heading: The area prior to the building of Ethelburga Estate
paragraphs: Prior to the Second World War, the area west of Battersea Park (the future Ethelburga Estate) consisted mainly of terraced houses dating from late nineteenth century.  (Ill.1)  During World War Two, the area was heavily bombed with buildings on Ethelburga Street and surroundings streets destroyed or badly damaged.    The area of total destruction, indicated in black on the bomb damage map, is approximately where Ethelburga Tower was subsequently built. (Ill. 2)

factsheet.heading: The planning of Ethelburga Estate
paragraphs: The earliest plan for Ethelburga Estate (LCC Architects Department  1955) show six 11 storey blocks standing in an open parkland extending from Battersea Park. (Ill. 3)  The finalised plan for Ethelburga Estate, circa 1960, shows the future Ethelburga Tower as a 23 storey block of 123 flats in an estate of generally four storeys. (Ills 4,5,6)   The plan  was revised in 1964 with the height of Ethelburga Tower reduced to 17 storeys with 98 flats to lessen its impact on surrounding areas.   (Ills 7,8)
The Survey of London describes the delay in the construction of Ethelburga Tower:

“Most of the estate went to tender in January 1963, when Tersons Ltd won with a bid of over £2 million. The main element delayed was the future Ethelburga Tower, to whose height local residents had objected. A tribunal upheld their case, forcing the LCC to lop off six storeys. 
‘This means that 32 families who are at present badly housed will lose their chance of a decent home’, grumbled the Housing Committee’s chairman. Otherwise the construction phase seems to have gone well, most of the estate being occupied in 1965.

factsheet.heading: Ethelburga Tower:   design and construction
paragraphs: The architect in overall charge of the Ethelburga Estate project was Herbert Gornall Gillett of the London County Council Architects Department.  The structural engineers for Ethelburga Tower were Ove Arup & Partners.   The builders were Tersons.   The building has an in situ reinforced concrete frame with storey height precast concrete panels to the north and parts of the east and west elevations.   The balcony floors are also precast concrete.

Of the 98 flats, 32 flats on the east and west sides are maisonettes (on two levels) with 17 one bed and  17 two bed flats (on a single level) on the south side.   Lift landings are on odd floors, opening on to double height access galleries,  with flats on the “mezzanine” floor reached by the stair.  There are 36 storage units in the basement.

factsheet.heading: Ethelburga Tower: occupation and use
paragraphs: The first residents moved into the block in 1967.   Ownership and management of the building passed  from the Greater London Council to Wandsworth Council in 1978.     Flats were purchased by council tenants under the government’s “right to buy” legislation from the 1980’s onwards and also under Wandsworth Council’s own “priority sales” scheme.

The building was refurbished in 1990 when flat No1a was created by infilling the covered area on the ground floor on the north side of the block. The precast concrete panels, which were originally dark grey exposed aggregate, were painted as part of the concrete repair programme in 1990.  (Ill.9)  The windows, which were originally timber,  were replaced with UPVC in 1990.  (Ills 10,11,12)

Internal decorations were carried out in 2001/02.  Paint which had been applied to the slate walls in the entrance hall was removed at this time.  A further phase of external repairs was carried out in 2007/08.

factsheet.heading: Ethelburga Tower Residents' Association (ETRA)
paragraphs: ETRA was founded in 1998 and is an accredited residents’ association of Wandsworth Council.   Membership is open to all people living in the block, whether they are council tenants, leaseholders, or sub-tenants of leaseholders.  The membership fee is £1.   ETRA also receives a grant from Wandsworth Council.   Since 1998, ETRA has worked with Wandsworth Council to implement a series of small improvements, including the creation of the cycle store and improved lighting.  The building is occasionally used for filming.

factsheet.heading: Ethelburga Tower: “At Home in a High-Rise”
paragraphs: In 2009, Mark Cowper, a photographer then living in Ethelburga Tower, staged an exhibition of photographs at the Geffrye Museum (now the Museum of the Home) of individual living rooms in Ethelburga Tower.  The photographs were taken “as found”, without tidying or advanced preparation.   Mark said: "I was curious to see what other people had done with their flats... It's fascinating how much self-expression can go into one small space".  https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gallery/2009/mar/28/ethelburga-tower-pictures-by-mark-cowper

factsheet.heading: References
paragraphs: Mark Cowper: ‘Everyone likes to peek into someone else’s world’, The Guardian 28th March 2009  https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/gallery/2009/mar/28/ethelburga-tower-pictures-by-mark-cowper
Obituary: HG Gillett,  “Other lives”, The Guardian, 26th August 2010  https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/aug/26/hg-gillett-obituary
Ed. Colin Thom, Survey of London, Volume 50. Battersea Part 2: Houses and Housing, pp115-116
